content: The Act titled "Internet Stopping Adults Facilitating the Exploitation of Today's Youth Act (SAFETY) of 2007" introduces penalties for conducting financial transactions to facilitate access to child pornography. Offenders can face fines or up to 20 years in prison. The Act "Internet Stopping Adults Facilitating the Exploitation of Today's Youth Act (SAFETY) of 2007" addresses financial facilitation of access to child pornography, imposing penalties of fines or up to 20 years in prison. The Act "Internet Stopping Adults Facilitating the Exploitation of Today's Youth Act (SAFETY) of 2007" imposes penalties on Internet content hosting providers or email service providers who knowingly facilitate access to child pornography, with fines or up to 10 years in prison. The Act "Internet Stopping Adults Facilitating the Exploitation of Today's Youth Act (SAFETY) of 2007" defines an email service provider as a person who offers Internet-based services for sending, receiving, storing, and retrieving emails, and also handles the content and recipient list of emails. SEC. 4. CHILD PORNOGRAPHY REPORTING. The Act addresses internet facilitation of child pornography and exploitation of children. Child Pornography Reporting: Amends the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 to impose fines on providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services for knowingly or negligently failing to report child pornography. Fines range from $150,000 for initial failure to $300,000 for subsequent failures. Providers failing to report child pornography may face civil penalties of up to $50,000 for initial failure and up to $100,000 for subsequent failures. The Federal Communications Commission has the authority to levy these penalties and will establish regulations in consultation with the Attorney General to enforce them. Providers failing to report child pornography may face civil penalties of up to $50,000 for initial failure and up to $100,000 for subsequent failures. The Federal Communications Commission has the authority to levy these penalties and will establish regulations in consultation with the Attorney General to enforce them, including appropriate administrative review of any civil penalties imposed. SEC. 5 amends Section 1956(c)(7)(D) of title 18, United States Code to include various offenses related to child pornography. SEC. 6 introduces record retention requirements for internet service providers. SEC. 6 introduces regulations for Internet Service Providers to retain records like subscriber information for compliance with court orders. Failure to comply may result in fines and imprisonment. SEC. 7 amends penalties for sexual exploitation of children to 20 years or life imprisonment. SEC. 8 increases penalties for activities related to material involving the sexual exploitation of children. Section 2252(b) of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for activities related to material containing child pornography. The amendments include longer prison sentences ranging from 15 years to life for certain offenses. Section 2252A(b) of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for certain offenses related to child pornography. The amendments include longer prison sentences ranging from 15 years to life. Additionally, there is a requirement to place warning marks on commercial websites containing sexually explicit material. In this section, the term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission, and "website" is defined as any publicly accessible collection of material on a computer server. The term "sexually explicit material" is defined as material depicting sexually explicit conduct, excluding material with restricted access. The term "Internet" refers to the interconnected worldwide network of computer networks, while "Internet access service" enables users to access content and services offered over the Internet. The curr_chunk discusses the labeling requirement for websites that contain sexually explicit material, stating that such websites must include specific marks and notices prescribed by the Commission. Failure to comply with this requirement is prohibited for websites primarily operated for commercial purposes. The Commission will establish marks or notices for websites with sexually explicit material within 90 days of the Act. This requirement does not apply to telecommunications carriers or Internet service providers. The act prohibits the retrieval, hosting, formatting, or translation of communications without altering the content. Violators may face fines and imprisonment for up to 15 years for repeat offenses under specific sections of the law. The act prohibits various offenses including aggravated sexual abuse, child pornography, and sex trafficking of children under specific sections of the law. SEC. 11 of the act adds new RICO predicates related to embezzlement, theft, and bribery. SEC. 12 authorizes $30,000,000 for the Innocent Images National Initiative annually from 2008 to 2012.
